Situation1: It seems your I04iend is confused about the meeting spot, and you need to send a message right now to confirm it.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story: I gripped the steering wheel, my phone buzzing insistently in the cup holder. My friend, Sam, had texted three times already, each message more frantic than the last. We were supposed to meet up after my shift, but now he was at the wrong spot, confused and waiting for my reply. I knew if I didn’t clear things up right now, he’d think I was blowing him off again. But as I glanced at my phone, the road ahead narrowed—orange cones funneled traffic into a single lane, and a cluster of kids in bright backpacks waited at the crosswalk. The urge to grab my phone and text Sam was overwhelming; I didn’t want another misunderstanding between us. But as a taxi driver, I was responsible for every life around me, especially in a school zone. My heart pounded as I wrestled with the urge to be a good friend and the duty to be a safe driver, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me at once.
